82E4A3B0A8EE442688202DE40BDBAA7F.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

7DF23093FBF448EF9BCA467487E293C3.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

FDDF0397F271456A9723C95D1EE4D313.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

1CE1DEC7D9294E12988C4624E8431EBD.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

CB59D1E801FC44E494C788C8E46375FA.description: Showcase one's skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry.

47CC336E0F4A4FB7AD43086CFBAE6462.description: Relate one's work placement experience to personal and career goals.

A3EF5DF9A47F4C57A8EDAEED389A28D4.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

A2E40DE6898D4EA79B25AC0092821B70.description: Document one's experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization's 'raison d'être;' and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one's employability.

25AE17D677D94D8B9E310E667B5795D3.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

8A4C3A879C5F4B6D8E5205B6E7BEB145.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

EFAFC17E87B34B8A8891F2CB20E34663.description: Reflect upon one's performance during the interview.

4A6914AE25104D0394371D4B88FC8EA8.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

5B8089E5C9114D598F3012F3AB2DCF29.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions.

5ABCC447C31B4540B95272FD992D135F.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement. These may include: What is my schedule of work hours?, Who is my supervisor?, What should I wear?, When will I be provided with safety training?, What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement?, Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance?, What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it, provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?, Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

9FE21C0CA621430A921885ABFD467153.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

32C5009223B943069DD573637EA16667.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

3920C3708CDE4F399A3012F82B5394D3.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement.

5E797594B68A4EE3B740BB942629981A.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations.

B35F1A756674453AB95AA30ED470D39A.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

D8B2FFC8348D49E58AC645B0C2A88596.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III - Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know - the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate - in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse - work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

4BB905D25F884B02874DBAAEBF71D709.description: Investigate the roles and training requirements of a wildlife rescuer or wildlife rehabilitator.

36D81171F030479D9F44EA893C4A6A7B.description: Explain the contributions of careers in environmental non-government organizations to the search and monitoring of wildlife data.

FAA80F357B53457D9A6756C4B6FB85A3.description: Describe the responsibilities (e.g., chemical testing, pollution tracking and population counting) that are characteristic of careers in the field of environmental monitoring.

86EA13761E2348E8ADE23D6694EE94EA.description: Research environmental technicians' contributions (e.g., identify wildlife, population planning and land planning) to the consulting industry.

0CCE6DDB786049BB8D129FD6D2EC1253.description: Explore the training requirements to become a taxidermist or a producer of fish reproduction mounts.

C3F0AF86C4914DB0B5C5D5177ABCE36F.description: Investigate the roles (e.g., enforce regulated use of natural resources and manage interactions between wildlife and humans) of a conservation officer.

CD8DE5EE618F4338B0D6BD55B833153B.description: Research and explain the competencies (e.g., knowledge of game patterns, safety precautions and local regulations) required to be a hunting or fishing guide.

14D5E0DDD92447359BD4D2CD6F4D3013.description: Investigate ecotourism and related job opportunities (e.g., interpreter, and hunting and fishing guide) in Saskatchewan.

CD0D3245AF374FD898D6DCD7FE3923AB.description: Explain the objectives (e.g., protect habitat from monocrop agriculture, increase numbers of huntable species and provide optimum habitat for wildlife) and the ethical considerations (e.g., 'unfair' advantage over wildlife, unnatural genetics and disease susceptibility) of game farming.

15E228B194DB47B291E187C12990B2D2.description: Discuss game farming (e.g., wild boar, elk, whitetail, ostrich and bison) as an alternative to domestic livestock.

CCD1E39E2DC2404E89C2F2A32421361E.description: Explore the benefits (e.g., restoration of threatened species and diversity to food supply) and drawbacks (e.g., spread of disease, use of antibiotics and habitat loss) of aquaculture.

B1E0FC70BE7546369640FBD67C2ACA81.description: Examine how wildlife contributes to the economy of an area.

CEFE452B797446B980C8B6F25EB0314A.description: Investigate characteristics of specific careers in the field of wildlife and habitat management.

36B09DA8DCAF46978D160ABE5F3084F3.description: Specific Careers in Wildlife and Habitat Management (Optional)

0C0468F2E9A84F18AA63952010556B22.description: Research short and long-term goals for the management of a specific habitat or species.

D35A9334E4324C1EB0BD3F0A67E78EFF.description: Analyze a variety of issues and problems affecting the management of wildlife and habitat, such as: preservation versus conservation; legislation versus no legislation; species management versus ecosystem management; and, wildlife habitat preservation versus commercial and agricultural land modification.

3CF36FB0F97A464C8DBE50AB0B84C8EC.description: Outline the steps in developing an existing management plan (e.g., Saskatchewan Wildlife Federation, Ministry of Environment and Wildlife Advisory Committee, Nature Conservancy of Canada Natural Area Management Plans), including: state goals and objectives; collect data and conduct research; gather government and non-government input; consider alternatives, consequences and potential conflicts; select a course of action; implement action plan; monitor and evaluate outcomes; and, make recommendations and revisions.

539C05B8476A4C69B8B269277B8A5196.description: Explain how organizations use “community science” (i.e., applications to record observations) to assist in monitoring wildlife.

E0B4582BB5F048D0A6C80909A8E54367.description: Investigate the agencies responsible for managing Saskatchewan’s game animals.

C960F14A93DC4DB0AD0683884227533D.description: Describe the goals of the Saskatchewan Fish and Wildlife Development Fund.

6F875FAA2AB94C0894EA09D75C946BF3.description: Explore the role of regulated hunting, fishing and trapping in wildlife and habitat management and conservation, including: allocating revenue from licenses to wildlife and habitat protection; managing high populations to protect damaged ecosystems; tracking disease; and, preventing over-harvesting.

40760A11CDB34873A6DF68B7526374A4.description: Compare preservation (i.e., protect endangered areas and species) and conservation (i.e., proper use of areas and species) as they relate to wildlife and habitat.

8BCC7F52D7BB401DAE7F121F0BE44030.description: Explain the purpose (e.g., ensure long-term viability of species and ecosystems) of wildlife and habitat management programs.

8D8FA3E12F6A4D8CA13D4D9989F0A082.description: Examine the importance of wildlife and habitat management plans.

B08DFCB4F15A475CA07A49D77BD739F6.description: Plan and prepare a meal cooked over a fire or gas stove.

4FB77D3650354F27AEDEF995711198B1.description: Prevent food from spoiling and attracting wildlife by using safe food storage practices (e.g., appropriate containers, bear-proof containers and hanging food).

8C41CBCFACC84870B2CADF9D3127BD39.description: Explain the risks of consuming untreated water and methods (e.g., filters, chemical treatment and boiling) of water purification.

B915E869350A41C39292AF0641B64A06.description: Develop a budget for the menu and other excursion costs.

0216C48AEFDD4103AFCC8A44E94FDDD6.description: Plan appropriate menus for the excursion and group.

4BF24593AF0948098CBBC6B24FE2AEB4.description: Identify factors (e.g., pain, cold, hunger, fatigue and fear) that affect the ability to cope with emergency conditions in the outdoors.

7040849CAB344B03B0B80A212A423789.description: Establish plans for emergency situations such as extreme weather conditions, fire, injury, illness, becoming lost or animal threats.

77B2C8279F1841CF91E984C65E373446.description: Practise communication routines (e.g., whistle commands and satellite phone) in emergency situations both within and outside of cell phone range.

81580BCA238941CDBB8C338B6A44B140.description: Discuss the importance of carrying a personal survival kit (e.g., compass, personal medications, knife and emergency blanket).

6FA9EA47CBB649A4901D93BC5DB1C6B7.description: Conduct an equipment check prior to excursion to ensure functionality, including: operating Naptha gas stoves (i.e., lighting and unflooding); erecting tents; and, verifying stock in First Aid kit.

13F1E44342CE4D85A256A086CFC0DA74.description: Select and collect appropriate equipment for the excursion.

97785E54A7114E27BFF9F465ABC2CB5E.description: Explain and demonstrate use of the principles of layering clothing, including: base layer (i.e., wicks moisture away from the skin); mid layer (i.e., insulates to preserve body warmth); and, outer layer (i.e., protection from weather).

EEA710CCE04648A8973DEAB319A9B24F.description: Reflect upon the traditional stories of the land where the overnight excursion will take place.

FA23815A8FC744788EA1B331B514AE86.description: Discuss the importance of land acknowledgements (e.g., naming the traditional peoples of the area, identifying the treaty and partnerships with local Indigenous people) when participating in overnight excursions.

51B769426B434052B1C6B2638CEA3286.description: Plan and facilitate an overnight outdoor excursion.

F306A1FF79E440AE9D768FEB3C531F0D.description: Describe how seeking alternatives to euthanizing an injured animal is an act of stewardship.

9CAD6B78742F4EED8F61B2AD2D53496F.description: Explain why relocation of wildlife is an ineffective method for dealing with “nuisance” wildlife, including: wild animal babies left orphaned when their mother is trapped and removed; danger to the relocated animal in other animals' territory; and, difficulty finding food, water and shelter in unfamiliar areas.

957C854E10AA48F2A9E47D028E2C5624.description: Explore humane ways of coping with “nuisance” wildlife, such as: deterring or hazing the animals with unpleasant smells (e.g., cider vinegar), sounds (e.g., music, air horn) or bright lights; sealing off any denning areas; and, using repellants.

637FA3C299854F71BEFB6887CB964451.description: Explain the negative impact of imprinting on young wildlife and the risks (e.g., no fear of humans, territorial behaviour and difficulty interacting with their own species) when young wildlife imprint on humans.

F9E99C7368C24C72B80CB11D8E0868FA.description: Outline steps that can be taken to prevent capture myopathy from occurring in wildlife.

A5C24B57FCD445ADAF30FD03A0EAC611.description: Define “capture myopathy” and identify its symptoms.

328B15060C6B47448B1EBAB2F1B31655.description: Research the purpose and function of wildlife rescue and rehabilitation organizations in Saskatchewan.

B364C7C138B249A19D6E51D49885BF97.description: Investigate wildlife rescue and rehabilitation practices in Saskatchewan.

C43CDE93DF8847F690F6F7D791CC328A.description: Explore the role that sustainable gardening and farming practices have on protecting wildlife and habitat, such as: organic practices; vermicompost; peat-free gardening; zero tillage; and, permaculture food forest.

404DD11122EB47BA87399391569CF00A.description: Explain the role of public (e.g., government) and private (e.g., industry) organizations in managing and protecting wildlife and ecosystems.

D259E23506114B35A13DD49B8AE55985.description: Investigate the role of protected spaces (e.g., parks, wildlife and wilderness areas, migratory bird sanctuaries, ecological reserves, world heritage sites, private land and grazing reserves) in managing ecosystems.

3B360FA879ED42D58DFAF9FF937153F5.description: Explore management strategies (e.g., migration corridors, bounties, euthanasia and relocation) that enable wildlife and humans to coexist.

797C52C8E320482F879EE0C32FE8096C.description: Discuss the contributions and goals of different stakeholder groups (e.g., hunters, conservation organizations, government, recreational users, farmers and Indigenous people) in managing interactions between wildlife and society.

2741576F9F694D34B41B6CCE8067D78F.description: Compare the diversity of wildlife and plant species in areas of high and low human population.

9DD75CA6A6884F41BCC7D6634C5F0BA0.description: Discuss the effects of human populations on wildlife (e.g., distribution, diversity and abundance of species) and habitat in the local area.

62AFFB0FE9E24ADBB7DEEC0A15D2C050.description: Discuss the cultural and traditional use of natural resources with an Elder or Knowledge Keeper.

FE16B39405B74BF88D10EFB85C2BB195.description: Explore human effects on wildlife species and spaces.

0945429773A64FFCAB7622890AA2FB45.description: Investigate trapping training opportunities (e.g., Humane Trapper Education Program).

FB3355D55F0F48559B8FB5455338EF20.description: Describe measures taken to ensure the safety of others (e.g., pets and humans) when setting traps.

864E6FDCC8754138A87E4C00202914B5.description: Explore the process involved in marketing and selling furs and factors that influence market value.

B18595711EFC4A91AF4B233D10AEB638.description: Investigate methods to process and preserve furs, including stretching and tanning hides.

C2FC696DE1A7437794E549F31C03036B.description: Explain circumstances that justify trapping outside of winter months (e.g., nuisance management, predator control, flooding and beaver activity).

87373FF0B3264DF09609E98979A41214.description: Explore the value in harvesting fur when it is prime (i.e., December to March).

FF8B0A9495D74C8FA95F41172263CD3D.description: Research the humane trapping practices (e.g., harvesting, methods and equipment) as outlined by the Agreement of International Humane Trapping Standards.

82F2C95B7B4E4F52A533BD968BA09A5A.description: Describe the characteristics and purpose of different types of traps (e.g., foot-hold and body-gripping) and snares (e.g., foot, leg, neck and power).

5749EBA5BF6B4F37BA018D55F4A4B6FB.description: Compare the differences in trapping regulations in the Northern Fur Conservation Area and Southern Fur Conservation Area of Saskatchewan.

DD4A5D2A35A14E2180647041D7A8E8E4.description: Outline the steps to obtain a trapper's license.

E4CD9341DB2C4869AE7095CE1AE59B3D.description: Explain the rights (e.g., furs) and responsibilities (e.g., annual fee) of owning a trapline.

912D73E5630542B081EDA8C2F4877655.description: Examine federal, provincial and municipal laws governing trapping.

4632AC167A044755AF48552F0B5CD5C9.description: Explore the reasons for trapping, such as: need for sustainable textiles and clothing; sustenance; trade; and, management of animal populations.

CFD9AFAF94D24417A4780FCE6243D499.description: Discuss how the fur trade impacted exploration and the colonization of western Canada.

A703E4238D6040308941308087368CB7.description: Explain the Twelve Commandments of Firearm Safety.

08B7CB6E854A4A0781034FFF222A29B0.description: Investigate hunting training opportunities and firearm licensing requirements (e.g., Hunter Safety Course and Possession and Acquisition License).

3BE1D7D887E34B36A3F39370FF25A0A8.description: Discuss how hunting and firearm use may be made available to persons with physical disabilities, including those with visual impairment.

D7FBEE1E71544CDFA01AA82253585C19.description: Describe safe practices for storing, transporting, handling, maintaining, loading and sighting-in firearms.

694EEAC8636949FEBA5210108F9D362D.description: Investigate ammunition considerations (e.g., size of bullet, casing and gun powder in the casing).

707F4AECC5FC44498139F40AF20D1798.description: Discuss the ethics of using the appropriate firearm calibre for the target game species.

5B42114FCD6B402FA3F5C2B595EB3D28.description: Describe the basic components of rifle and shotgun ammunition.

DE22165E411F49339BB311E80DFB8A83.description: Explain the operation of various firearms, including the types of action, ammunition and function of sights.

C0B9C88CE24A4DF6BF2C5A80FBBD95A8.description: Categorize commonly used hunting firearms (e.g., rifles, shotguns and black or modern powder firearms) according to their distinguishing features and purpose.

CC463E6E4BE44B87869B8E2351052581.description: Research the history and evolution of firearms (e.g., muzzle-loaded rifles, breech-loading rifles, repeating firearms, semi-automatic firearms, openand telescopic-sights).

6D35DE4EA7BA4761894EF96AFFD45E3E.description: Discuss how the introduction of firearms affected the Indigenous way of life in Saskatchewan.

2661AC7147A54FDA81A0D0843E8C9D48.description: Explore the evolution and safe use of firearms.

311B74F8D1EB4EB083D963EB66D9C07C.description: Explore archery training opportunities (e.g., National Archery in the Schools Program) in Saskatchewan.

0446D856F1184048AFA3B91E2BC0FA55.description: Investigate the rules and safety practices to follow at an archery range.

7D98ECC26397494599FADC821EFAECA5.description: Discuss the importance of inspecting archery equipment prior to use.

B81F3AC6B13B4F1A9832F65447F9A9B2.description: Describe precautions that can be taken to prevent injury to both the archer and to others.

C8EE5D7A2B154F97A24ED5F7A32789F8.description: Demonstrate proper use and maintenance of a bow, including: correct shooting form; tuning the bow; and, sighting-in a bow.

24039D42984F4CCDA246BC0289EB318C.description: Explain the “rule of first blood” (i.e., ethical and sportsmanship way of determining who claims an animal shot by two hunters).

6C9691797B2B4E1E890C910A4BFCCDBC.description: Explore the considerations unique to crossbow hunting (e.g., restrictions in seasons and management zones).

264D80DDA87F465D8FABB9D87330E53F.description: Research specific regulations for bowhunting in Saskatchewan regarding seasons, equipment and tagging requirements.

6C46219788D845F1870FE92606F3CC60.description: Explain how to determine appropriate draw length and draw weight.

7A9F972F73F141FEBFBEF9F6C165A840.description: Compare the characteristics of arrow points used for large game, small game and target practice.

5BB6259A8D5849D3BC82C1604CD161A2.description: Explain the importance of matching bows and arrows.

7ABDBD1471F6413D97BA524A7257D3E6.description: Describe the function of basic parts (e.g., limbs, riser and bowstring) of various bow styles (e.g., recurve, longbow, compound and crossbow).

99598DD3271C4349BA371E3F99A95CD7.description: Discuss the advantages (e.g., quiet, early season and less intrusive) and challenges (e.g., wind, limited range, required strength and necessary accuracy) of bowhunting.

D6EA951009B549EEAB284F4891579132.description: Research the history and evolution of archery equipment (e.g., spear, atlatl, simple bows and compound bows) in different cultures.

B35CC477E0224B5980A1F4F07E992A7D.description: Investigate materials (e.g., stones, wood from local trees, and sinew and bone from animals) used to make traditional Indigenous bows and arrows.

A09BFEE047BC41EFB5EAE5C19E263B0D.description: Explore the history and types of bowhunting.

F1DCB321B95347C18D185A4FB4FFB5C2.description: Investigate the differences in fishing regulations (e.g., equipment and limits) in national parks and other regions.

925C000FE6474004BE133A7E6A276BCE.description: Discuss the fishing license regulations for different user groups (e.g., First Nations people, youth under 16 and seniors).

350188BD61B34BBA8EA92CFAA59AEE08.description: Research fishing regulations and associated legislations (e.g., protection and conservation of fish, conduct of fisherman and small vessel legislation) that provide a legal standard of conduct for game fishing.

72C475E83F3347A5A56BA292492CA9F6.description: Discuss the importance of referring to the Saskatchewan Anglers Guide for information such as season dates, zones and limits.

7B80FB010FF9434F923D818BA9CF0F72.description: Describe the fish-harvesting process, including considerations such as: filleting technique; leaving one inch of fish skin; preservation options (e.g., canning, pickling, freezing and smoking); and, performing an act of mindfulness for the harvest.

F7922127632D42658633E9E7C7D65646.description: Compare the techniques for care of table fish and trophy fish.

C9D695FB5FDA4D99AB209D93E65712FE.description: Describe ethical fishing practices, such as catch and release, barbless hooks and lead-free tackle.

6ACAA4DC8684405BA5FFC4158E26CD00.description: Experiment with different angling techniques (e.g., ice fishing, open water fishing, bait fishing and fly-fishing) for different purposes.

98438D45238E4EF6A6F863947810C19E.description: Explore how to craft fishing equipment, including a tip-up or rod.

93FA9A97BB8F4621B203C25A96398B2A.description: Explain proper maintenance of common fishing equipment, including: dry out rods and tackle when not in use; loosen drag tension for storage; and, oil the reel.

393B48B10FC64AE99EA8BD2FB405EB2D.description: Demonstrate safe fishing practices, such as using barbless hooks, keeping hooks and lures in tackle boxes, wearing eye protection and using dehooking tools to remove hooks.

7B3E9A3A50C6431EA5E9D7B222AB7C06.description: Discuss who is eligible, and how to apply, for an angling license.

BA56A3D58DAA4699985AEB69ABD58EC5.description: Demonstrate safe angling and fishing practices and understanding of regulations.

136061431C27476C9AA8D722C15B1190.description: Angling and Fishing - Safe Practices and Regulations (Optional)

C1E768E285524BACB7C5E8C9C6F5F85B.description: Explain the risks of consuming unfamiliar plants.

965C36FD5F214834AE622EF3FD2EC13C.description: Explore the nutritional value of consuming local plants, such as: berries; cat tail tubers; fiddle heads; mushrooms; young stinging nettle; wild onions and garlic; daylilies; marigolds; and, dandelions.

B41F48BEE7AA4FE882F2B7D9D268FDA2.description: Investigate the relationship between soil and vegetation (e.g., tamaracks and wet soil, birch trees and rich soil, and jack pine and sandy soil).

D0F83E917DB049B3A5A76DFDB9385919.description: Research how vegetation can be used as a navigational tool.

C3E5FB700B4543D7997E00D01D4AFBCB.description: Research how vegetation can be used as a navigational tool.

6F6C5CDCC51C4063831F18B98ADE000B.description: Refer to a variety of resources (e.g., books, Knowledge Keepers and technological applications) to identify local plants.

F41127642C434A4095D16483ED42972E.description: Explain how the ecozones of Saskatchewan, and their corresponding treaty territories, affected the food and shelter needs of Indigenous people.

63EA91F8422F4BCC9FB52C08E0F5F430.description: Discuss traditional ethical harvesting practices (e.g., take only what is needed and leave tobacco).

225B821FE9BE485F925F9772A39A29E5.description: Discuss the cultural and traditional significance of local plants with an Elder or Knowledge Keeper.

F37398203044484AB819557BF44EB5B1.description: Explore traditional and nutritional uses of local plants.

68DC38AB4EDD4ACAB81A03055D23105A.description: Demonstrate how to determine when a fire is fully extinguished.

15698C8D44E54B75A69D129514030B2A.description: Practise safely lighting and maintaining fires in favourable conditions with common ignition sources, tinder and kindling.

6AB982BF79804E5FB11726D2D3D83BBB.description: Explain the importance of gradually increasing the size of kindling.

303B2C79E7E34F9C8324E7FA1DFAACCA.description: Discuss commonly used types of household tinder (e.g., cotton ball and newspaper).

221CCD7308F147D083967F1B12F815A3.description: Prepare the fire site with consideration for fire safety, including: having water nearby for extinguishing; being prepared with a shovel to smother with dirt; avoiding low-hanging canopy; and, clearing the ground to prevent unintentional spreading.

2678601801074B30BBE26CAE012F29D4.description: Discuss the risk of using accelerants when lighting fires.

1DD7C848227E4053BA447FCCE5154CDB.description: Discuss how controlled and maintained fires can be used for a variety of purposes, including: warmth; cooking; protection; signalling; place to gather; and, environmental protection (e.g., protect against invasive species and prevent forest fires).

1BEBB1A956B842D7B684B232738B9478.description: Demonstrate respect for the natural environment by conserving fuel and by practicing an act of mindfulness when harvesting material to burn.

DD36F39F32794B54A2B650B5CFF952E8.description: Investigate the significance of fire in other cultures.

87F1052C8E274F698003B0FC9C94D865.description: Discuss the cultural and traditional significance of fire, including sacred fires, with an Elder or Knowledge Keeper.

842E0124BC664B7E98464653507E8A44.description: Demonstrate respectful and safe basic fire-building skills.

98C095FF64854F4A91DA0392323FF77B.description: Practise safe knife skills with basic knife craft projects (e.g., whimmy diddle, curl sticks and carving wood).

AA7ADA4705D140C0B92A5918342762B7.description: Explain how to identify a serviceable knife blade (e.g., sharp or dull).

82BD6E2FF953400E859FB717962ADD1E.description: Discuss the consequences of inappropriate or unsafe knife use, including harm to self or others (e.g., cuts and injuries) and harm to the environment (e.g., carving initials into trees and stripping birch bark for fire starter from a live tree).

09B407E5860B414DBEA99685ACAAD4BB.description: Categorize knives according to their construction, such as: folding knife; fixed blade; grind types (e.g., flat grind, scandi grind); and, steel options (e.g., stainless, high carbon, Damascus).

8A9E75A65FE9484FB709AA257CAD18FF.description: Discuss the use and functionality of different types of knives (e.g., bush, kitchen, hunting and filleting).

07CE51D12FA349DCA1BFA110072643B9.description: Identify parts of knives, including the spine, blade and finger guard.

714AA7287C9B4E2EBC6CDDA0F8471374.description: Compare types of knives for safety features (e.g., locked and fixed blade).

2B1B06A3A8DB43A69B3D11BF37945E75.description: Demonstrate safe knife procedures, such as: only use a sharp knife; avoid the “circle of blood” (i.e., the area within the radius of the arm and blade length combined) of someone holding a knife; carve with elbows on knees; work with knife outside the “triangle of death” (i.e., triangle between knees and torso); cut away from self and gripping hand; sheathe knife after use; and, properly pass knife to someone.

CF93774BC51949A88E829CDAFDAB88BB.description: Investigate materials (e.g., stone and bone) used by Indigenous people to create traditional knives.

5FC5849B1B9942FEB877F6373379CBB9.description: Practise “Leave No Trace” principles by dismantling shelters when they are no longer required.

CD18B908D13549DB9EC6EBEBA7EA9E5D.description: Describe optimal snow conditions and construction of various snow shelters (e.g., quinzhee, snow cave and igloo).

60F8F8D4D67A40FB86185F7810881CDB.description: Experiment with various types of tarp-based shelters, such as: wrap or cocoon; pup-tent; A-frame; and, Mors Kochanski's “super-shelter”.

4E7851001C0847DAB17A29C04C6557E7.description: Demonstrate how to construct various styles of natural shelters, such as: debris (i.e., material gathered from the forest floor); log shelter; lean-to; and, A-frame.

420814811510484B9E9857D2A35A1626.description: Examine factors that affect shelter choice (e.g., number of people requiring shelter, available materials and their cost, weather and animals).

BBAFE59C66EC4326BB2DFCAFA28651B1.description: Explore natural environmental features that provide shelter from the elements, such as depressions in the ground, holes from tree roots and lowhanging branches.

0F3B7EB0A04C4C098EE23D9EFBA5CA64.description: Compare the differences between building shelters for emergency and recreational situations.

96DFE07D39664BCCA4720807D1F9F9E3.description: Demonstrate mindfulness (e.g., take only what is needed) and gratitude (e.g., offering tobacco) when harvesting materials for shelters.

D38964BC4EAF44B68192F591437A0C2D.description: Practise a variety of sustainable shelter-building techniques.

4AA10B0AB7D44D0B875EDE3678641CCB.description: Experiment with the application of paracord in paracord crafts (e.g., lanyards and bracelets).

23C225111A3649C0AF2CBC0B38A3DA74.description: Investigate the usefulness of paracord in bushcraft survival.

F870D1418C6440E4B37C82F524BA8F26.description: Explain the factors to consider in rope making (e.g., strength and breaking point).

55517B14C577428F8E8AE4F3EBCB64F6.description: Experiment with the craft of rope making, including: preparing fibres (e.g., hemp, stinging nettle and animal hair) for spinning into yarns; spinning yarns into cords; twisting cords into strands; and, twisting strands into rope.

BCA7AACC30C8460FBDE4B1B4A2C64A79.description: Apply knot-tying skills to related outdoor skills, such as tying up tarp shelters, tying fishing knots (e.g., fisherman's knot and palomar knot) and tying nets.

ECEB87836CF14195AC712710C2E1E45A.description: Discuss the importance of strong cordage and efficient knot skills in Indigenous ways of living off the land.

2DE6038996104E1193738D87768768CB.description: Apply knot-tying skills in a variety of situations.

C98A292914B447D5A7C2515F7AAB0427.description: Explore the uses of a GIS application such as Sask Interactive Mapping.

504FECD5A12A4DFBAC154B1239804CEB.description: Compare the function and use of a GPS and Geographical Information Systems (GIS).

7E1ECEBE76984ECBB3E355BDE3DE5854.description: Plan a route for others to follow using waypoints.

A32236677B754BF097A1CE5C57A46D94.description: Explain the purpose of waypoints when using a GPS.

EA56536160644AEF8667D5CDFEB36205.description: Explore how common hand-held technology such as cell phones can be used as a navigational tool.

B1D84481EAA047FD90A5BBD48EAD6A65.description: Compare the benefits of using a map and compass or a Global Positioning System (GPS) to navigate in different situations.

DDB4E8D18E2F4BCC9513B9646B42DF20.description: Navigate a route using a compass and map.

144FB88F36284CD9B422297AA1DA71C1.description: Calculate declination to travel on a bearing using a compass.

F7B8C10E58504603AF75B130D4D42982.description: Explain declination and its considerations for compass navigation.

61686FB925844E38A8015AA52CCF6B02.description: Orient and interpret a map using the legend and topographical lines of elevation.

6112BE1B2F3E4EDE982FB06762DE3ADA.description: Apply navigational skills in a variety of situations.

85A9EEF113BD4F67B746D23575CDFCBF.description: Engage in outdoor evening activities such as star gazing, identifying moon phases and night hiking.

5B42084C37AC4FD3ACF35FF80D5021B4.description: Practise cross-country ski techniques (e.g., diagonal stride on flat ground, herringbone uphill and snowplough downhill) for different purposes.

620A69647EAC45C9B1F4ADD775105D40.description: Experiment with different snowshoe skills (e.g., step and kick turns, striding, stamping and edging).

2B2CCCA6F13C4D888CEC914780209C13.description: Demonstrate safe techniques in climbing activities (e.g., high ropes and wall climbing).

4C62A8015694474C96C8C439C692D049.description: Apply hiking skills (e.g., pacing, adjusting pack, stretching and resting) when hiking in various terrains, such as urban and wilderness treks.

C2DD8D27A19D4DBCA1B207E6628F93BD.description: Exhibit use of basic cycling techniques such as hand signals, braking safely and gear shifting to accommodate for changes in incline.

57BE43021B264F7BAFB1C21980BDFAD8.description: Practise canoe strokes (e.g., forward and reverse, draw, pry, j-stroke or stern rudder, sweep and brace) for different purposes.

761F99FB6D0A4D93A1C8D3DFA5C6155B.description: Demonstrate basic canoe safety and rescue skills, such as getting in and out of a canoe, carrying a canoe, t-rescues and effective throw bag technique.

7B1A454DEF5843C7BA06505F0CC490F9.description: Explain the “Swim to Survive” standard of the Life Saving Society.

EA94CE5944A44D65ABAAC86F1D6F4A81.description: Display basic swimming skills such as floating, treading water and kicking and stroking.

F9B83150BCB84EB78DBC636FC7A89262.description: Compare nutritional and hydration requirements when participating in light to heavy exercise.

261DE4E534764589A74EE8FBBA44D310.description: Explain the role of physical conditioning in safe and comfortable outdoor experiences.

46B3363479774CCE8F0251A4B1BEFEB1.description: Participate in a variety of outdoor activities.

D9A4188C3C294C2F86945189C5E0EA2F.description: Explore opportunities for, and benefits of, being certified in first aid.

924D7986D6034C9CA667105F8D18F114.description: Compare the items appropriate to include in a personal first aid kit (e.g., band-aids, personal medications and sunscreen) and a group first aid kit (e.g., medical gloves, gauze and bandages).

B6D7FAF04B354A03BD60DAB5F4F6B387.description: Explain the additional risks of emergency situations that occur in the wilderness, such as lack of proximity to treatment and lack of sterilization.

8731E49A436D41F2BAFE1D97CED845AD.description: Explore prevention and treatment of injuries that could be acquired from engaging in outdoor activities, such as: cuts, burns and blisters; sprains; anaphylaxis; broken limbs; hypothermia and hyperthermia; and, frostbite and sunburn.

4D0D385034AF426F87144586B3B02040.description: Define primary and secondary surveys in first aid.

F8AAAAF13C614076A17410A2606AB698.description: Identify injuries common to an activity (e.g., head injuries while cycling) and steps taken to prevent them (e.g., wearing a helmet).

F7EE27248AA94FF29D2B513A0C645163.description: Describe how to ensure the safety of the person providing first aid (e.g., gloves and scan the area).

9FD0D5864B7848CA94B844C80C2B48D6.description: Explain the terms “first aid,” “first aider” and “Good Samaritan law.”

CEBA6E4DC1D14D29B82FA62F7F33A19C.description: Explore basic first aid skills used to treat minor to severe injuries.

074BB28CCF1443389BA71FA8B1B76121.description: Discuss options for dealing with food waste (e.g., completely burning and packing out).

6613EEEF54974ECE9C21921676E70433.description: Demonstrate respect for wildlife by keeping distance and storing food securely.

B725EE8BDE844C0587E9A4BBCE351621.description: Explain considerations for minimizing the effects of building a fire, including: using existing fire rings; using deadfall for fuel; burning fuel to white ash; and, packing out campfire litter.

CFB34921C0BD47959C244219186B5A8C.description: Investigate minimal impact alternatives to cooking over a fire (e.g., envirostove, fire box and gas stove).

51965C712191405AA299F4C8514679D8.description: Explore options for proper disposal of human waste outdoors, such as: digging catholes; portable toilets; and, packing out waste (e.g., toilet paper and feminine hygiene products).

D77B10B7C0224DC6A956D0AB6C6D4C66.description: Demonstrate respect for the natural setting by: minimizing campsite alterations; avoiding damage to trees and plants; and, leaving natural objects where they are found.

C32109470568404988CEF29167559460.description: Compare the effects on the land of camping and traveling on and off durable surfaces.

27D33048A059435FB08B0F5353B69F0D.description: Discuss the importance of planning and preparing in advance of excursions, including to ensure safety and minimize resource damage.

A77F759EE69848BEB5B6E5184D5D6559.description: Practise the “Leave No Trace” principles on outdoor excursions.
